content: The "Minority Inclusion in Clinical Trials Act of 2015" emphasizes the need to increase representation of underrepresented communities in clinical trials, as stated by the National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities. The National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities is directed by Congress to include ways to increase underrepresented communities in clinical trials. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants for expanding opportunities for scientists and researchers, as well as promoting the inclusion of underrepresented minorities in the health professions. Support for institutions in underrepresented communities for workforce development. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants to eligible entities that focus on health workforce development in underrepresented communities, including historically Black colleges, Hispanic-serving health professions schools, Hispanic-serving institutions, and tribal colleges and universities. The curr_chunk focuses on institutions that historically produce or train underrepresented minority health professionals, including historically Black colleges and universities, Hispanic-serving health professions schools, tribal colleges and universities, and other institutions with programs to recruit and retain underrepresented minority health professionals. The curr_chunk highlights the criteria for institutions to enroll underrepresented minorities in health professional programs, including partnerships with communities and health professional associations. The curr_chunk outlines the requirements for institutions to enroll underrepresented minorities in health professional programs and how funds received under a grant can be used to enhance diversity through workforce diversity programs. Workforce diversity programs aim to enhance diversity in mental health care professions by considering minority status in qualifications. Activities may include educational outreach, scholarships, postbaccalaureate programs, academic enrichment, pipeline programs, mentoring, and internship programs. The curr_chunk discusses various activities eligible for grants under a workforce diversity program, including pipeline programs, mentoring, internship programs, and leadership training. Grantees are required to submit reports summarizing and evaluating their activities. The term "Asian-American, Native American, and Pacific Islander-serving institutions" is defined within the section. The grantee must submit annual reports summarizing and evaluating activities conducted under the grant. The term "Asian-American, Native American, and Pacific Islander-serving institutions" is defined in this section. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2015 through 2020. Eliminating disparities in maternity health outcomes. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with various healthcare organizations, will conduct research to eliminate disparities in maternal health outcomes. The national organizations will conduct research and expand access to services to eliminate disparities in maternal health outcomes. They will establish a demonstration project to compare interventions and assess effectiveness. The Secretary will conduct a demonstration project in up to 8 States to compare interventions and assess effectiveness in reducing disparities in maternity services and outcomes. States will be selected based on applications specifying regions and populations to be served, as well as criteria to ensure representation of affected communities. The Secretary will conduct a demonstration project in up to 8 States to compare interventions and assess effectiveness in reducing disparities in maternity services and outcomes. Criteria will ensure representation of affected communities and a variety of tested models with existing evidence base for effectiveness. The project will involve consultation with local and regional provider organizations. Demonstration projects in consultation with local and regional provider organizations will be conducted from January 1, 2015, to December 31, 2019. Grants for evaluation and monitoring will be provided to states and healthcare providers participating in the project. States must report data to the Secretary as specified for evaluation purposes. The State participating in the demonstration project must report data to the Secretary for monitoring outcomes, costs, and quality of maternity care. The Secretary will submit a final report to Congress by December 31, 2020, on the project results. The Secretary will evaluate the rationale for bundled payments made by the State under the project and submit a final report to Congress by December 31, 2020. SEC. 6. HEALTH DISPARITIES EDUCATION PROGRAM. The Secretary will establish a health and health care disparities education program in collaboration with various entities to inform professionals and the public about reducing racial and ethnic disparities. This program will include public awareness and outreach campaigns targeting the general public and the medical community. The Secretary will disseminate scientific evidence on racial and ethnic disparities in health care through public awareness campaigns targeting the general public and medical community. This includes disparities not attributable to known factors, as outlined in the 2002 Institute of Medicine Report. The Secretary will disseminate information on disparities related to age, disability, socioeconomic status, gender, and sexual orientation among racial and ethnic minorities. This includes addressing linguistic and cultural barriers in healthcare for those with limited-English proficiency. The Secretary will disseminate information on disparities related to age, disability, socioeconomic status, gender, and sexual orientation among racial and ethnic minorities. This includes addressing linguistic and cultural barriers in healthcare for those with limited-English proficiency, ensuring access to language services, data collection on various demographics, providing educational initiatives to healthcare providers on disparities, and assessing the impact of programs on raising awareness and available resources. Design and implement educational initiatives for healthcare providers on health disparities and assess the impact of these programs in raising awareness and providing information on available resources. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2015 through 2020 is provided for this section.
